comments:
Clicks to reproduce: start Eclipse, File/New Project (or ), Java/Java Project, Next, enter project 
name, Finish, then select project in package Explorer, New Java Class, Source Folder=<project 
name>, package=<empty>, Name=<some name>, any combination of modifiers, click on Finish 
doesn't do anything. The same procedure works on WinXP (version 2.1). 

This also happens with version 2.1.1.

System: Mac OS X 10.2.6,
Andre, can you please have a look. This seems to be Mac specific.

Since I cannot reproduce this problem (and nobody has ever reported this problem both for 2.1.1 
and the 3.0 stream) I need some more information.

I don't quite understand your 
"Name=<some name>, any combination of modifiers, click on Finish doesn't do anything"

Does it mean that the "Finish" button is enabled but doesn't do anything?
Or is it disabled?

Is there anything in the .log or on the Mac OS X console?

Created an attachment (id=5906)
Log file for the Can't create Java class

The button is enabled. I just sent the log file and the console is displaying much the same, here 
are first few lines:

JspUIPlugin: startup
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.core 4 2 Aug 29, 2003 08:34:48.853
!MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.jdt.core".
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.crimson.jaxp.DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl
	at javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance(DocumentBuilderFactory.java:139)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.VMDefinitionsContainer.parseXMLIntoContainer(VMDefinitionsCo
ntainer.java:368)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.LaunchingPlugin.getVMDefinitions(LaunchingPlugin.java:558)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.LaunchingPlugin.processVMPrefsChanged(LaunchingPlugin.java:4
94)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.LaunchingPlugin.propertyChange(LaunchingPlugin.java:444)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Preferences.firePropertyChangeEvent(Preferences.java:578)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Preferences.setValue(Preferences.java:1181)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JavaRuntime.saveVMConfiguration(JavaRuntime.java:1239)
<more...>

You seem to have the Xerces library installed in one of the Java extension folders (which is not 
recommended).
As a result this library appears on the system wide boot class path of the Java VM and Eclipse picks 
it up automatically. However, since Eclipse requires a different version, you see the crash in the 
DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl.
Move Xerces (or any other non-standard) libraries into a different folder and add it to your project 
from within Eclipse by editing the class path.

You were absolutely right. I checked all my jar files in /Library/Java/Extensions and came accross 
google.jar which includes crimson parser. After moving it away the problem disapeared.

jar tvf /Library/Java/Extensions/googleapi.jar | grep crimson

Thanks.
We should really protect Eclipse from these kinds of errors.
